Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: The Digital Spinneret
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will build upon recent advances in nanotechnology and laser processing of materials to pursue the large-scale production of stoichiometrically pure silicon carbide (SiC) fibers which are very difficult to obtain by other means. The transition from laboratory scale to industrial production requires a sea change in manufacturing approach. The proposed research will investigate the parameters involved in creating a "Digital Spinneret" (DS), a novel technology platform which enables the production of large qualities of high-quality fibers. The Phase I project demonstrated feasibility of the Digital Spinneret to produce many fibers in parallel; the Phase II research will extend and optimize this manufacturing method.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project will be the enabling of scaled production of high-purity ceramic fibers for application in military and aerospace (turbomachinery, rockets, advanced structures), automobile, medical, energy, and other industries that require advanced materials with exceptional strength, stiffness, heat resistance, and/or chemical resistance. These are fast-growing fiber markets with great potential, and with a collective size exceeding $1 billion. The projected energy footprint of this production method is 1/1000th that of competing methods, providing a huge cost advantage.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Modest as it is, fiber making figures amongst the highest achievements of human ingenuity. It is documented as early as 3,000 BCE in ancient China and its fundamental principles have persisted to this day in all spinning technologies. The Digital Spinneret (DS) — developed under this National Science Foundation (NSF) Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR)  award — represents the first fundamental departure from the seminal fiber making technology in nearly 5,000 years. The DS addresses in particular materials that have so far resisted or been hard to make into fibers because of their extreme properties. But those properties are also why such fibers are now highly prized in advancing the state of the art of critical technologies, such as advanced composite materials. These are engineered materials designed to withstand the extreme environments associated with highly efficient energy generation, jet engines, nuclear power, rockets, and armor to cite a few. Beyond material properties, the DS is fundamentally an Additive Manufacturing (AM) process rooted in the now well-established technique of Laser-Induced Chemical Vapor Deposition (LCVD). The DS offers not only new materials in fiber form, but also offers new fiber packaging and opens the door to novel fiber-coating technologies that have never been available before. The new packaging delivers fibers in the form of 'ribbons' of continuous parallel filaments, which are likely to transform the state of the art in composite materials manufacturing. The new coating capability presents an opportunity for continuous and -- never before available -- discontinuous multilayer coatings. The combinations of these DS features open new vistas on what composites can achieve ranging from a new generation of jet engines, to accident tolerant nuclear fuel and multifunctional (aka "smart") structures.

To date, all the fiber making prior art -- going back thousands of years -- have proceeded from squeezing a viscous liquid, gel, paste, or a plastically deformed precursor through small holes or slits called “spinnerets”. Once through the spinneret, streams are left to re-solidify, polymerize, coagulate or congeal into filaments for possible post-processing as “green fibers”. This method of course precludes a large number of materials, which have extreme properties that are not amenable to traditional fiber making methods. But is also because of these extreme properties that these same materials are of high interest in fiber form for extreme applications. Some ceramic materials for example do not have a liquid phase, neither do they tolerate plastic deformation that would allow the formation of filaments. Ad-hoc geopolymer chemistries, such as the Yajima process, have been developed to yield green fibers for subsequent processing into near silicon carbide ceramic fibers at great energetic expenses. Even then, the level of impurities left in the resulting fiber is such that performance is degraded well below the level anticipated for the nominal material. The same can be said of the dimensional quality of intensively processed fibers for which it is difficult to maintain dimensional and material properties over lengths greater than a couple inches.

In Phase I, this NSF SBIR project set out to demonstrate that fibers that cannot be made by traditional spinneret processes could be "laser printed" using the DS. Once proof-of-concept was reached, Phase II concentrated on the development of a pre-production prototype aimed at scaling up throughput. 

Pursuant to the principles of LCVD, the DS ‘extrudes’ a fiber out of a laser focus in a chemical vapor environment (Fig.1). The process is massively parallelized by replication of the laser foci. As the lattice of fibers grows into corresponding laser beams it is conveyed away at a rate consistent with susta...

It is documented as early as 3,000 BCE in ancient China and its fundamental principles have persisted to this day in all spinning technologies. The DS addresses in particular materials that have so far resisted or been hard to make into fibers because of their extreme properties. These are engineered materials designed to withstand the extreme environments associated with highly efficient energy generation, jet engines, nuclear power, rockets, and armor to cite a few. Beyond material properties, the DS is fundamentally an Additive Manufacturing (AM) process rooted in the now well-established technique of Laser-Induced Chemical Vapor Deposition (LCVD). The DS offers not only new materials in fiber form, but also offers new fiber packaging and opens the door to novel fiber-coating technologies that have never been available before. The new packaging delivers fibers in the form of 'ribbons' of continuous parallel filaments, which are likely to transform the state of the art in composite materials manufacturing. The new coating capability presents an opportunity for continuous and -- never before available -- discontinuous multilayer coatings. The combinations of these DS features open new vistas on what composites can achieve ranging from a new generation of jet engines, to accident tolerant nuclear fuel and multifunctional (aka "smart") structures. This method of course precludes a large number of materials, which have extreme properties that are not amenable to traditional fiber making methods. But is also because of these extreme properties that these same materials are of high interest in fiber form for extreme applications. Ad-hoc geopolymer chemistries, such as the Yajima process, have been developed to yield green fibers for subsequent processing into near silicon carbide ceramic fibers at great energetic expenses. The same can be said of the dimensional quality of intensively processed fibers for which it is difficult to maintain dimensional and material properties over lengths greater than a couple inches. In Phase I, this NSF SBIR project set out to demonstrate that fibers that cannot be made by traditional spinneret processes could be "laser printed" using the DS. Once proof-of-concept was reached, Phase II concentrated on the development of a pre-production prototype aimed at scaling up throughput. Pursuant to the principles of LCVD, the DS æextrudesÆ a fiber out of a laser focus in a chemical vapor environment (Fig.1). The process is massively parallelized by replication of the laser foci. As the lattice of fibers grows into corresponding laser beams it is conveyed away at a rate consistent with sustained continuous production; as it were, laser-printing a ribbon of parallel filaments.
